section_id: ## 2. The Fractal Set as a Dynamic Geometric Data Structure

hints.label: def-fractal-set-dynamic-tessellation
hints.title: Fractal Set as Dynamic Tessellation
hints.content:
64: :label: def-fractal-set-dynamic-tessellation
65: 
66: The Fractal Set F = (V, E_CST, E_collision) can be viewed as encoding a time-evolving tessellation of state space:
67: 
68: **At each time slice t**:
69: - The vertices V_t = {v_i : t(v_i) = t} represent walker positions {x_i(t)}
70: - These positions define a **Voronoi tessellation** Vor(t) and dual **Delaunay triangulation** DT(t)
71: 
72: **The CST edges E_CST encode tessellation updates**:
73: - An edge (v_i(t), v_j(t+Δt)) specifies how the Voronoi cell V_i(t) transforms into V_j(t+Δt)
74: - The collection of all edges between time slices defines the **scutoid tessellation** of spacetime
hints.section: ## 2. The Fractal Set as a Dynamic Geometric Data Structure
hints.raw_directive:
61: The Fractal Set is not merely a record of walker trajectories; it is a **dynamic geometric data structure** that encodes the evolution of spatial tessellations.
62: 
63: :::{prf:definition} Fractal Set as Dynamic Tessellation
64: :label: def-fractal-set-dynamic-tessellation
65: 
66: The Fractal Set F = (V, E_CST, E_collision) can be viewed as encoding a time-evolving tessellation of state space:
67: 
68: **At each time slice t**:
69: - The vertices V_t = {v_i : t(v_i) = t} represent walker positions {x_i(t)}
70: - These positions define a **Voronoi tessellation** Vor(t) and dual **Delaunay triangulation** DT(t)
71: 
72: **The CST edges E_CST encode tessellation updates**:
73: - An edge (v_i(t), v_j(t+Δt)) specifies how the Voronoi cell V_i(t) transforms into V_j(t+Δt)
74: - The collection of all edges between time slices defines the **scutoid tessellation** of spacetime
75:

hints.label: thm-scutoid-update-types
hints.title: Scutoid Classification and Triangulation Updates
hints.content:
84: :label: thm-scutoid-update-types
85: 
86: The scutoids in the Fractal Set tessellation fall into two categories, corresponding to two types of triangulation updates:
87: 
88: **Type 1: Prismatic Scutoids (Local Moves)**
89: - **Geometry**: Prism-like 4D polytope with congruent top and bottom faces
90: - **Causal Structure**: Single parent → single child (no cloning)
91: - **Physical Process**: Walker moves continuously via SDE
92: - **Triangulation Update**: **Vertex position update** - move vertex x_i → x'_i and perform local Lawson flips
93: - **Complexity**: O(1) amortized (small number of flips)
94: 
95: **Type 2: Non-Prismatic Scutoids (Teleportation)**
96: - **Geometry**: Scutoid with different top/bottom combinatorial structure
97: - **Causal Structure**: Parent-child cloning relationship
98: - **Physical Process**: Dead walker removed, new walker inserted at parent's position
99: - **Triangulation Update**: **Delete-and-insert** operation - remove old vertex, insert new vertex
100: - **Complexity**: O(log N) (point location) + O(1) amortized (flips)
hints.section: ## 2. The Fractal Set as a Dynamic Geometric Data Structure
hints.raw_directive:
81: Each scutoid in the 4D tessellation corresponds to a specific type of update to the 3D triangulation:
82: 
83: :::{prf:theorem} Scutoid Classification and Triangulation Updates
84: :label: thm-scutoid-update-types
85: 
86: The scutoids in the Fractal Set tessellation fall into two categories, corresponding to two types of triangulation updates:
87: 
88: **Type 1: Prismatic Scutoids (Local Moves)**
89: - **Geometry**: Prism-like 4D polytope with congruent top and bottom faces
90: - **Causal Structure**: Single parent → single child (no cloning)
91: - **Physical Process**: Walker moves continuously via SDE
92: - **Triangulation Update**: **Vertex position update** - move vertex x_i → x'_i and perform local Lawson flips
93: - **Complexity**: O(1) amortized (small number of flips)
94: 
95: **Type 2: Non-Prismatic Scutoids (Teleportation)**
96: - **Geometry**: Scutoid with different top/bottom combinatorial structure
97: - **Causal Structure**: Parent-child cloning relationship
98: - **Physical Process**: Dead walker removed, new walker inserted at parent's position
99: - **Triangulation Update**: **Delete-and-insert** operation - remove old vertex, insert new vertex
100: - **Complexity**: O(log N) (point location) + O(1) amortized (flips)
101:
